description_en: A detailed examination, analysis, or critical inspection of one or multiple subjects designed to discover facts.
A unique proper name or character sequence that identifies this particular study.
A name that designates this study.
The non-unique initials or abbreviated name used for identification.
A statement or piece of writing that provides details on this study.
The conditions which, if met, make an person eligible for participation in this study.
An investigator who is responsible for all aspects of the conduct of a study.
Name of study contact.
An email address for the purpose of contacting the study contact person.
A plan specification comprised of protocols (which may specify how and what kinds of data will be gathered) that are executed as part of this study.
The date on which this study began.

The date on which the concluding information for this study is completed. Usually, this is when the last subject has a final visit, or the main analysis has finished, or any other protocol-defined completion date.
The status of a study or trial.
An integer specifying the quantity of study subjects enrolled in the study at the current time.
An integer specifying the quantity of samples collected at the current time.
The act of making data or other structured information accessible to the public or to the user group of a database.
The act of making data or other structured information accessible to the public or to the user group of a database.
One or more characters used to identify, name, or characterize the nature, properties, or contents of a thing.
The words or language units by which a thing is known.
Persons who are observed, analyzed, examined, investigated, experimented upon, or/and treated in the course of a particular study.

A unique proper name or character sequence that identifies this particular individual who is the subject of personal data, persons to whom data refers, and from whom data are collected, processed, and stored.
A backup sequence of characters used to identify an entity.

A person's concept of self as being male and masculine or female and feminine, or ambivalent, based in part on physical characteristics, parental responses, and psychological and social pressures. It is the internal experience of gender role. For practical reasons the lookups are limited to first and second-level entries, but can be expanded when needed. Note that 'Gender at birth', 'Genotypic sex' and any (gender-related) hormone therapies in 'Medication' are usually medically more relevant than this term.

Assigned gender is one's gender which was assigned at birth, typically by a medical and/or legal organization, and then later registered with other organizations. Such a designation is typically based off of the superficial appearance of external genitalia present at birth.
A biological sex quality inhering in an individual based upon genotypic composition of sex chromosomes.
Country of residence at enrollment.
Population category defined using ancestry informative markers (AIMs) based on genetic/genomic data.
The country that this person was born in.
The year in which this person was born.
The calendar date on which a person was born.
A findings domain that contains general subject characteristics that are evaluated periodically to determine if they have changed.
The age at which death occurred.
The calendar date of subject's death.
The year in which an individual derived.
The most significant institute for medical consultation and/or study inclusion in context of the genetic disease of this person.
A person acting as a channel for communication between groups or on behalf of a group.
Email address of the contact person or organization
Material or data related to this person that is not captured by this system though known to be available in other institutes such as biobanks or hospitals.
Reference to the study or studies in which this person participates.
A domestic group, or a number of domestic groups linked through descent (demonstrated or stipulated) from a common ancestor, marriage, or adoption.
A designation that has some relationship to motherhood.
Having to do with the father, coming from the father, or related through the father.
Any individual related biologically or legally to another individual.
Either of two offspring born from the same pregnancy.
The date for the first patient visit.
Any tissue from a fetus.
Genetic relatedness between individuals who are descendants of at least one common ancestor.
Reference to the study or studies in which this person participates.
The act of making data or other structured information accessible to the public or to the user group of a database.
